Now that we have a new congress and a new SoD, the possibility of coming up with an intelligent policy in Iraq exists. The question, of course, is what should this policy be?
 
 Stay the course: I think it's safe to say that Iraq is slowly tearing itself apart, and our current policies aren't preventing it. Some change in policy is called for.
 
 Leave now: Tempting. If the Iraqis want to kill each other, why should we stop them? It's their country, let them fix it. On the other hand, we broke it. We have some moral obligation to repair the damage we've caused. And whatever government rules after the civil war is going to be strongly anti-US. On the other hand, we also have an obligation not to get our troops killed for no reason. If we can't come up with some realistic plan to bring peace to Iraq than our troops are dying for no reason. If we can't come up with anything better, bailing might be the best choice.
 
 International force: Call in the UN as peacekeepers. Of course, given how insulting Bush has been to the UN over Iraq, the odds of pulling this off are about nil, but an internaitional force with a large Muslim contingent might be able to bring some measure of stability to the region, since they wouldn't be seen as an occupying force in the same way that we are. On the other hand, they might be prone to the same partisan issues we're already seeing.
 
 Split the country: Sunni and Shiite can't stand each other? Give them each their own country. Kurds too, while we're at it. Violates one of the major points of invading, and probably wouldn't work for a host of practicle reasons, but I thought I'd toss it in just for discussions sake.
 
 Any other ideas?
 
 
 At this point I'm really not sure that Iraq can be saved; civil war may be inevitable, followed by a strongly anti-US religious government. Pretty much like Iran. This is pretty high on the worst-case-scenario list, but I don't see an obvious way to avoid it at this point. If anyone has any thoughts, I'd love to hear them.

At this point, as Donald Trump remarked the US should "declare victory" and pull out. (Not that I consider Trump an expert, but I thought his remarks were as good as any.) They deposed Saddam, and they aren't going to be able to keep sectarian factions from warring over who willl have power. We can't make lemonade out of lemons here--moral obligations to fix the mess are meaningless if they are impossible to pull off.
daewoo

I am all for declaring victory an pulling out. The only problem with this is that the only people on the planet who will actually buy that a victory occured are the American hyper patriots. The rest of the planet will be snickering at us, and we all know it. To many americans, that is unacceptable. Essentially getting beaten and being forced out of Iraq with our tail between our legs by a bunch of poorly armed arabs is going to be a major blow to Americans ego and is going to be percieved by any sane person as a serious defeat. 
 
 I DO think it is likely that this defeat will further convince other Arab nations (like Iran, Syria, and even whatever Iraq eventually turns into) that they can act with impunity because the US is a purely paper tiger.

 Except that we weren't "beaten" per se. If this were a simple stand up fight it would be no contest. The problem is that this isn't a simple us vs. them situation. It's them vs. them vs. them, with us in the middle trying to tell them what to do. I doubt that most serious thinkers will believe we were forced out militarily. The failure here was in diplomacy and planning, not military.
 
 As for your concerns about America being perceived as a paper tiger, I don't think we need to worry. Granted, we can't occupy a middle eastern country, but when it comes to just blowing stuff up we're still the pros. As long as were not threatening to move into a country and take over its government I think we'll still be taken seriously.

 Maybe that's the key...we should just stick to blowing stuff up rather than trying to police the world and force nations into a democracy they don't want and we aren't prepared to recognize. We either need to realize this is a cultural and /or holy war and go in there and conquer with the idea that we are the superior civilization or ..... just leave. They have fought for thousands of years against each other, it is going to take a lot to change that region of the world. Our main problem is we don't have a lot of the world behind us. Most people seem to just want to look the other way as long as they are getting their oil.

 You've covered all the scenarios. This issue is, unless economic matters bury it, going to be the primary campaign issue for 2008. Bush is still attempting to salvage some semblance of being correct in his Iraq blunder for historical purposes, but I don't think the public or the new congressional majority is going to let him stall for two years and make it solely a Democratic Party problem as was his original intent. 
 
 I say, as I've always said, write a check and get out. We've already alienated most of the world with our Iraq policy, proved we can't properly occupy even a small nation like Iraq without unpopular conscription to provide adequate troop levels and we look like fools with this stay the course tripe. Let the chips fall where they may and start concentrating on cleaning up domestic matters. Israel as our ME gunslinger will provide enough ME problems for us and they're cheap compared to a $10-billion a month US occupation and continued US deaths. 
 
 The immediate problem in leaving Iraq for whatever reason(s) for both Democrats and current administration is going to be economics. Pull Iraq and the flow-through out and we have a negative GDP plus a lot of unemployed reserves and national guard. But that may not matter if 2nd quarter numbers head south.
